article.headline: Kansas State 84, Colorado 82
article.story: BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- With a 40-minute effort Colorado only wished it could have matched, Jeremiah Massey and Kansas State walked away with a win that could keep them playing in the postseason. Massey had 28 points and 19 rebounds and the Wildcats held off a late Colorado rally for an 84-82 victory Saturday, a win that will look good when the NIT goes looking for teams to fill out its bracket. "If we win some more, every step you take in that direction is a step in the right direction," K-State coach Jim Woolridge said. Sophomore Lance Harris added a career-high 20 for the Wildcats (15-10, 5-9 Big 12), who won their second straight after six consecutive losses and would likely need to win the Big 12 tournament to have a shot at the NCAAs. CU freshman Richard Roby made seven 3-pointers to hit 30 points for the first time in his career. The Buffs (13-13, 4-10), who are in 11th place and now lead only Baylor in the Big 12, trailed by 16 with 5 minutes left, but got it down to two twice inside the last 20 seconds. After Glean Eddy dunked to make it 84-82 with 9.1 seconds left, the Buffs fouled Harris, and he missed both free throws. Colorado got the rebound and got the ball to Marcus Hall, who rushed down and missed a layup, barely grazing the rim. Massey got the rebound and was called for traveling, but the buzzer sounded as the call was made and the Wildcats had just their third win away from home this season. "I totally would have thought it was my fault if we had lost," Harris said. "If Marcus Hall had hit that layup, I would have definitely blamed myself for overtime." But Hall didn't make it, and thus ended another disappointing day for the Buffaloes, who at halftime honored their only Final Four team on the 50th anniversary of the program's sole appearance in the national semifinals. For the first 35 minutes of this one, the current Buffs looked about a half-century away from playing that level of basketball. "We waited too long to play as hard as we needed to play," coach Ricardo Patton said. "We waited too long to care." Colorado allowed the Wildcats to shoot 56.9 percent from the floor, one week after an embarrassing display at home against Texas A&M, which shot 60 percent en route to a way-too-easy 92-77 victory. When the Wildcats weren't shooting up a storm, they were grabbing their own rebounds. Of their 39 boards, 13 came on the offensive glass and most of those resulted in points. Massey was the key to it all. The senior, who is in the top 10 in Big 12 scoring and rebounding, was relentless most of the game -- pounding the glass, working the middle and establishing himself as the best player on the court, except maybe for Roby. "He plays extremely hard," Patton said. "He plays at a high energy level. That's how you've got to play at this level to be successful." Colorado had its moments late in the game, but even after the Buffs used a 12-0 run to cut their deficit to four with 2:05 left, they got outhustled by Massey and couldn't get the stops they needed to get over the hump. Leading 76-72, Kansas State answered by pounding the ball down to Massey, who got fouled and made two free throws. Hall answered with two free throws of his own, but Massey responded with an offensive rebound and a stick back to push the lead back to six and set up the frantic finish. The Wildcats lost 82-81 last year on a shot with 3 seconds left. "I was just hoping it wasn't going to happen again," Massey said. Jayson Obazuaye had 15 points for Colorado and Andy Osborn had 13. Fred Peete finished with 10 for K-State, which goes for its third straight win next Wednesday at Kansas.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
